1985 ''[[Mask]]'' }} '''Cher''' ({{IPAc-en|icon|ˈ|ʃ|ɛər}};{{cite web| url = http://inogolo.com/pronunciation/d1638/Cher| title = Pronunciation of Cher| work=inogolo| accessdate =2010-05-26}} born '''Cherilyn Sarkisian'''; May 20, 1946) is an American singer, actress, television personality, director, record producer and entrepreneur. Well known for having worked extensively across media, she has won an [[Academy Award]], a [[Grammy Award]], an [[Emmy Award]], three [[Golden Globe Award]]s, and the [[Best Actress Award (Cannes Film Festival)|Best Actress Award]] at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] for her work in film, music and television. She is the only person in history to receive all of these awards. Referred to as the [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Goddess of Pop]] for being an influential figure in [[popular culture]], she is also known for continuously reinventing both her music and image, her distinctive [[contralto]], the considerable [[eclecticism]] of her work and her outrageous imagery which have been known to induce controversy. Cher first caught the eye and ear of the public in 1965 as one-half of the [[pop rock]] duo [[Sonny & Cher]], which have popularized a peculiar smooth sound that competed successfully with the predominant [[British Invasion]] and [[Motown Sound]] of the era. After a period in which the duo became obsolete thanks to the rise of the drug culture, she re-emerged in the 1970s as a television personality with her shows ''[[The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour]]'' and ''[[The Cher Show|Cher]]''. With the latter, she became a fashion trendsetter with her daring [[Bob Mackie]]-designed outfits, and was noted as being the first woman to expose her navel on television. At the same time, she established herself as a solo artist with chart-topping hits such as "[[Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)]]", "[[Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves]]", "[[Half-Breed (song)|Half-Breed]]", and "[[Dark Lady (song)|Dark Lady]]". After the duo separated in 1975, she had successful delves into disco music before becoming a top-earning live act in Las Vegas. In the early 1980s, Cher made a critically-acclaimed appearance on Broadway and starred in the film ''[[Silkwood]]'', which earned her a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress]] in 1983. In the following years, she established herself as one of the most acclaimed film actresses of the decade, starring in a string of hit films that includes ''[[Mask (film)|Mask]]'', ''[[The Witches of Eastwick (film)|The Witches of Eastwick]]'', and ''[[Moonstruck]]'', for which she won the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]] in 1988. Throughout the late 1980s and early 1990s, she made a musical comeback by releasing a series of multi-platinum rock albums and hit singles such as "[[I Found Someone]]", "[[If I Could Turn Back Time]]", and "[[The Shoop Shoop Song (It's in His Kiss)]]". After facing professional struggles by appearing in a series of cosmetic infomercials in the mid-1990s, she returned to popularity by making her directing debut in the film ''[[If These Walls Could Talk]]'' (1996) and releasing the biggest-selling single of her career, "[[Believe (Cher song)|Believe]]", which was also the best-selling single of 1998 and 1999. Cher ended her three-year-long [[Living Proof: The Farewell Tour]] in 2005 as the most successful tour by a female artist at that time. In 2008, she signed a US $60 million per-year deal with [[Caesars Palace]] in Las Vegas to perform a series of shows titled [[Cher at the Colosseum]], which ended in February 2011. Biographer [[Mark Bego]] says of her impact: "No one in the history of show business has had a career of the magnitude and scope of Cher's".{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=3}} Called "an authentic feminist hero" by ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'' magazine and the "Queen of the Comeback" by ''[[The New York Times]]'', she has been praised by critics for first bringing the sense of reinvention and self-actualization into entertainment industry. She has sold more than 100 million records worldwide and is recognized as one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]]. She is the only artist to have notched a number-one single on a ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' chart in each of the past six decades. == Early life == Cher was born Cherilyn Sarkisian in [[El Centro, California]], on May 20, 1946. Her father, John Sarkisian, was an [[Armenian American]] truck driver and [[drug addict]] with a gambling habit, and her mother, Georgia Holt ([[married and maiden names|born]] Jackie Jean Crouch), was an aspiring actress and model with Irish, English, German and [[Cherokee]] descent.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=17}}{{cite web|last=Cheever |first=Susan |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20110424,00.html |title=In a Broken Land |work=People |date=1993-05-17 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Her parents had a stormy relationship, eventually divorcing in [[Reno]], when Cher was ten months old. Holt and John married and divorced two more times. The third of Holt's eight marriages was to actor John Southall, the father of Cher's half-sister, actress [[Georganne LaPiere]]. Although their marriage ended when Cher was nine years old, she considers Southall her real father and remembers him as a "good-natured man who turned belligerent when he drank too much".{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=18}} As Holt married and divorced, the family moved from place to place (including New York, Texas and California){{harvnb|Parish|Pitts|2003|p=147}} and often had little money. At one point, Holt had to put Cher in an orphanage. Although they met every day, Holt and Cher found the experience traumatic. Cher's family noticed her creativity when she produced the musical ''[[Oklahoma!]]'' for her teacher and her class. According to biographer Connie Berman, "Cher got a group of girls together and directed and created the dance routines. Since she couldn't get the boys to take part, Cher acted the men's roles and sang their songs. Even at that age, she had an unusually low voice."{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=19}} Despite the difficult times and the instability of her mother's marriages, Cher wanted to be famous since childhood, but felt that she was "unattractive" and "not very talented". She later commented in an interviewer, "I couldn't think of anything that I could do ... I didn't think I'd be a singer or dancer. I just thought, well, I'll be famous. That was my goal."{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=21}} [[File:Cher HS Yearbook.jpg|thumb|left|170px|Cher in high school years]] In 1961, Holt married bank manager Gilbert LaPiere, who adopted both Cher and her half-sister and enrolled them in a private school, [[Montclair College Preparatory School|Montclair Prep]], in the prosperous community of [[Encino, Los Angeles]]. Like Cher's stepfather, the fathers of Montclair Prep students were financially successful. Such "posh" surroundings presented a challenge for Cher, as Berman wrote she "stood out from the others in both her striking appearance and outgoing personality." A former classmate recalled, "I'll never forget seeing Cher for the first time. She was so special ... She was like a movie star, right then and there ... She said she was going to be a movie star and we knew she would." Despite not being a top student, Cher was considered intelligent and creative. She usually got good [[Grade (education)|grades]] and did well in French and English. Later, as an adult, she would discover that she had suffered from a learning disability called [[dyslexia]]. She also achieved notoriety for her unconventional behavior: she would entertain other students during lunch hour performing songs and shock a few when she'd wear a midriff-baring top, being the first young woman in her crowd to do so.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=22}} She recalled later, "I was never really in school. I was always thinking about when I was grown up and famous." In those years, Cher had a brief relationship with actor [[Warren Beatty]].{{cite web|url=http://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800023318/bio |title=Cher Biography |work=Yahoo! Movies |accessdate=2012-10-28}} == Career and public life == === 1960s: Rise and fall === [[File:Sonny-and-Cher.jpg|thumb|left|Cher with [[Sonny Bono]] in 1966]] At the age of 16, Cher dropped out of school, left her mother's house, and moved in to Los Angeles with a friend, where she took acting classes and had numerous jobs to support herself. She came to dance in small [[nightclub|club]]s along Hollywood's [[Sunset Strip]], introducing herself to performers, managers, and agents.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=23}} According to biographer Connie Berman, "The teen did not hesitate to approach anyone she thought could help her get a break, make a new contact, or get an audition."{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=24}} Cher met [[Sonny Bono]], 11 years her senior, in November 1962 when he was working for "[[Wall of Sound]]" record producer [[Phil Spector]]. Shortly after, Cher's friend moved out of their apartment, and Cher took up Sonny's offer to move in with him as his [[Housekeeper (servant)|housekeeper]].{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=27}} They became inseparable friends, eventual lovers, and were unofficially married in October 1964.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=28}} Sonny brought Cher to Spector, who used her as a [[Backing vocalist|backup singer]] on many of his classic recordings, including [[The Righteous Brothers]]' "[[You've Lost That Loving Feeling]]" and [[The Ronettes]]' "[[Be My Baby]]", and produced her first single, the unsuccessful "[[Ringo, I Love You]]", issued under the name '''Bonnie Jo Mason'''.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic |class=artist |id=cher-mn0000107090 |pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic | Cher |last=Eder |first=Bruce |work=Allmusic |publisher=[[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Later in 1964, Cher emerged with Sonny as a duo, initially called Caesar & Cleo, and cut the singles "The Letter", "Do You Wanna Dance" and "Love Is Strange", with little attention. By the end of 1964, Cher (then known as Cherilyn) was signed to [[Liberty Records]]' [[Imperial Records|Imperial]] imprint, and Sonny came along as producer. Her second solo single, "Dream Baby", managed to get airplay in Los Angeles, becoming a local hit. Suspecting she was onto something, Cher released in 1965 her debut solo album, ''[[All I Really Want to Do (album)|All I Really Want to Do]]'', which was later described by Tim Sendra of [[Allmusic]] as "one of the stronger folk-pop records of the era". The album reached the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] top 20 and was on the albums charts for six months. The album's cover of the [[Bob Dylan]] song "[[All I Really Want to Do]]" peaked at number 15 on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]]. Meanwhile, [[Sonny & Cher]], as they were now known, signed to [[Reprise Records]] and released their first single, "[[Baby Don't Go]]". The song became a major local hit in Los Angeles (later peaking at number eight on the Hot 100), after which the duo moved from Reprise to the [[Atco Records|Atco]] label, a division of [[Atlantic Records]].{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100?chartDate=1965-10-09 |title=Hot 100 Songs & New Music: Oct 9, 1965 | Billboard Music Charts Archive |work=Billboard |date=1965-10-09 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Their first album, ''[[Look at Us]]'' (1965), spent five weeks at number two on the ''Billboard'' 200 and yielded the single "[[I Got You Babe]]", which topped the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 chart and became "one of the biggest-selling and most beloved pop/rock hits of the mid-'60s".{{cite journal|last=Bronson|first=Fred|date=1999-02-27|title=Chart Beat: Look at her|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=111|issue=9|page=88|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AQ4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA88|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}}{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/charts/hot-100?chartDate=1965-08-15 |title=Hot 100 Songs & New Music: Aug 15, 1965 | Billboard Music Charts Archive |work=Billboard |date=1965-08-14 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Several more mid-level hits followed, notably "Just You", "[[But You're Mine]]", "[[What Now My Love (song)|What Now My Love]]" and "[[Little Man (Sonny & Cher song)|Little Man]]", before "[[The Beat Goes On]]" returned the duo to the U.S. top ten.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/artist/sonny-cher/chart-history/105881 |title=Sonny & Cher Album & Song Chart History |work=Billboard |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Sonny & Cher charted 11 ''[[Billboard magazine|Billboard]]'' top 40 hits between 1965 and 1972, including six top-ten hits, and sold 80 million records worldwide.{{cite web|first=Krista |last=Smith |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/hollywood/features/2010/12/cher-201012 |title=Forever Cher |work=Vanity Fair |date=December 2010 |accessdate=2012-10-28}}{{cite web|author=They don't make songs like they used to |url=http://www.virginmedia.com/music/pictures/toptens/60s-stars-where-are-they-now.php?ssid=10 |title=Then: Sonny and Cher - 60s stars - where are they now? |work=Virgin Media |accessdate=2012-10-28}} At one point, they had five songs in the top 20, a feat equaled only by [[Elvis Presley]] and [[The Beatles]].{{cite web|url=http://cher.com/about-cher/about/ |title=About Cher |work=Cher.com |accessdate=2012-10-28 |first=Josiah |last=Howard}} [[File:Sonny and Cher David McCallum Man From Uncle 1967 Cropped.JPG|thumb|left|Cher on the set of the television series ''[[The Man from U.N.C.L.E.]]'' (1967)]] The duo became a phenomenon that resembled [[Beatlemania]],{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=jhy_BdXuSm4C&pg=PA207|page=207|accessdate=2012-10-28|title=The Classic Rock and Roll Reader: Rock Music from Its Beginnings to the Mid-1970s|author=Frank Hoffmann|author2=William E Studwell|author3=David Lonergan |date=1999-10-20|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0789001519}} traveling and performing around the world and, with their "warm harmony" and "smooth sound", competing successfully with the [[British Invasion]] of The Beatles and the [[Motown Sound]] of [[The Supremes]].{{harvnb|Parish|Pitts|2003|p=148}} According to writer [[Cintra Wilson]], "English newspaper photographers showed up when S&C were thrown out of the [[London Hilton on Park Lane|London Hilton]] [because of their outfits] the night they arrived — literally overnight, they were stars. London went gaga for the heretofore-unseen S&C look, which was neither [[Mod (subculture)|mod]] nor rocker. By the time Sonny and Cher got back to America ... they had to disembark from the plane onto the tarmac or be ripped to shreds by scrap-seeking fans."{{cite web|last=Wilson |first=Cintra |url=http://www.salon.com/2000/02/22/cher/ |title=Cher |work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]] |date=2000-02-22 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Following an appearance on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' in the fall of 1965 in which Sullivan had infamously mispronounced her name "Chur" during their introduction, the singer began spelling her name with an [[acute accent]] mark: '''Chér'''—a typographical feature she maintained through 1974.{{cite web|url=http://hotword.dictionary.com/burlesque/ |title=Learn what "burlesque" actually means, plus Cher |author=Hot Word |work=Dictionary.com |accessdate=2012-10-28}} The couple soon appeared on other hit television shows of the era including ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Hollywood Palace]]'', ''[[Beat Club]]'', ''[[Hullabaloo (TV series)|Hullabaloo]]'' and ''[[Shindig!]]''.{{harvnb|Parish|Pitts|2003|p=149}} Cher disguised her [[stage fright]] and nervousness with quick-witted barbs directed at her partner, and soon rose to prominence as the more outspoken and daring half of the team. With her exotic looks, she became a fashion trendsetter, helping to popularize fashions such as [[bellbottoms]] and "[[hippie]]" attire when she began wearing them in her shows.{{cite web|url=http://www.cherlasvegas.net/cher-biography.htm |title=Cher Biography - Cher Music |work=Cherlasvegas.net |accessdate=2012-10-28}} She also expanded her range by designing a line of marketed wardrobe. Between 1966 and 1967, Cher released the solo albums ''[[The Sonny Side of Chér]]'', ''[[Chér (1966 album)|Chér]]'' and ''[[With Love, Chér]]''.{{cite web|last=Sendra |first=Tim |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-sonny-side-of-cher-mw0000845862 |title=The Sonny Side of Cher - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}}{{cite journal|date=1966-07-17|title=Album reviews: Cher|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=78|issue=38|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=SA8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PT1|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}} They produced a series of hits, most notably "[[Bang Bang (My Baby Shot Me Down)]]", which reached number two on the Hot 100 and became her first solo million-seller;{{harvnb|Lazell|1989|p=90}} "[[Alfie (song)|Alfie]]", which received an nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] as the [[Alfie (1966 film)|Lewis Gilbert film]]'s theme;{{cite web|first=Bill |last=Lamb |url=http://top40.about.com/od/picksofartistsbest/tp/top-10-burt-bacharach-and-hal-david-songs.htm |title=Top 10 Songs of Burt Bacharach and Hal David |work=About.com |date=2012-05-25 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} and the U.S. top-ten hit "[[You Better Sit Down Kids]]". [[File:Good Times 3.jpg|thumb|Cher in ''[[Good Times (film)|Good Times]]'' (1967)]] As the 1960s came to a close, Sonny and Cher's openly monogamous, drug-free lifestyle had become obsolete, thanks to the rise of [[hard rock]], [[psychedelia]], and the drug culture.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=31}} Furthermore, according to Berman, "The heavy, loud sound of groups like [[Jefferson Airplane]] and [[Cream (band)|Cream]] made the folk-rock music of Sonny and Cher seem too bland." In an attempt to recapture their young audience, the duo produced and starred in the film ''[[Good Times (film)|Good Times]]'', in which they were featured in various "silly" skits. The movie was a flop. Cher continued her solo career by recording the unsuccessful albums ''[[Backstage (album)|Backstage]]'' (1968) and ''[[3614 Jackson Highway]]'' (1969), the latter for Atco Records.{{cite web|last=Viglione |first=Joe |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/backstage-mw0000845557 |title=Backstage - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}}{{cite web|last=Deming |first=Mark |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/3614-jackson-highway-mw0000694186 |title=3614 Jackson Highway - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Her relationship with Sonny also began to unravel, as he cheated on her repeatedly. According to ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine, "Bono tried desperately to win her back, telling her he wanted to marry and start a family." They were married after she gave birth to [[Chaz Bono]], who was born Chastity Bono on March 4, 1969.{{cite web|last=Green |first=Michelle |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20115644,00.html |title=Sonny on Cher |work=People |accessdate=2012-10-28}} The duo made another foray into film later in 1969, with Sonny producing ''[[Chastity (film)|Chastity]]'', intended to launch Cher as a major movie star. The film stiffed, costing the duo a good portion of their savings.{{cite web|url=http://encyclopedia.jrank.org/articles/pages/1578/Cher-originally-Sarkisian-Cherilyn.html |title=Cher (originally, Sarkisian, Cherilyn) |publisher=Online 1911 Encyclopedia Brittanica |accessdate=2012-10-28}} However, some critics noted that Cher demonstrated traces of good instinctive acting. At a low professional ebb, the duo put together a nightclub routine in Las Vegas. According to Wilson, "Their lounge act was so depressing, people started heckling them. Then Cher started heckling back. Sonny ... reprimanded her; then she'd heckle Sonny[.]" The heckling became a highlight of the act and turned it into a success, which led the couple to do guest appearances on prime-time shows.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|p=33}} === 1970s: Ressurgence in television, solo career=== [[File:Cher Don Knotts Sonny & Cher Show 1976.JPG|thumb|170px|left|Cher with [[Don Knotts]] at ''[[The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour]]'']] In 1970, Cher co-starred with Sonny in her first television special, ''The Sonny & Cher Nitty Gritty Hour''. A mixture of [[slapstick]] comedy, [[skits]] and live music, the appearance was a critical success.{{cite web|url=http://www.retroland.com/sonny-cher/#.UIi7xsWCmro |title=Sonny and Cher |work=Retroland |date=1999-02-22 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} They caught the eye of [[CBS]] head of programming [[Fred Silverman]] while guest-hosting ''[[The Merv Griffin Show]]'', and Silverman offered the duo their own variety show. ''[[The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour]]'' debuted in 1971 as a summer replacement series and was an immediate hit, returning to prime time later that year and ranking near the top of the ratings.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvparty.com/sonnycher.html |first=Billy |last=Ingram |title=Sonny and Cher Shows |work=TVparty! |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Silverman called the couple's success "an explosion. You could count on one hand the number of times this has happened in the history of television." The show received 12 [[Emmy Award]] nominations during its run, winning one for direction.{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/shows/sonny-cher-comedy-hour |title=The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour |work=Emmys.com |accessdate=2012-10-28}} The duo revived its recording career by releasing four albums for [[Kapp Records]] and [[MCA Records]] that included two top-ten hits: "[[All I Ever Need Is You (song)|All I Ever Need Is You]]" in 1971, and "[[A Cowboy's Work Is Never Done]]" in 1972.{{harvnb|Rees|Crampton|1999|p=926}} {{multiple image |direction = vertical |image1 = Sonny and Cher live 1971 Cropped.jpg |caption1 = Cher performing live in 1971 |width1 = 170 |image2 = Sonny & Cher 1973 Cropped.JPG |caption2 = Cher performing at ''The Entertainer of the Year Awards'' in 1973 |width2 = 170 }} Now 25, Cher continued to establish herself as a solo recording artist, enlisting the help of record producer [[Snuff Garrett]]. Cher's first solo [[Chart-topper|number-one hit]] was "[[Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves]]", which became the biggest selling single in the history of MCA Records at the time and earned her a nomination for [[Grammy Award for Best Female Pop Vocal Performance|Best Female Pop Vocal Performance]] at the [[1972 Grammy Awards]].{{cite web|first=Fred |last=Bronson |url=http://www.superseventies.com/sw_gypsystramps.html |title="Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves" - Cher |work=The Billboard Book of Number One Hits |publisher=Billboard |year=1988 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Released in September 1971, the [[Recording Industry Association of America|RIAA]]-certified platinum [[Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves (album)|album of the same name]] was recognized by critics for marking Cher's maturation as an artist with "highly intense performances" such as the U.S. top-ten hit "[[The Way of Love]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/grammy/popsolo.htm |title=Grammy Awards: Best Pop Solo Performance |work=Rock On The Net |accessdate=2012-10-28}}{{cite web|url=http://www.riaa.com/goldandplatinumdata.php |title=Gold & Platinum Searchable Database |work=RIAA |accessdate=2012-10-28}} The album peaked at number 16 on the ''Billboard'' 200 and remained on the chart for 45 weeks. In 1972, she released the commercially less successful album ''[[Foxy Lady]]'', an all-ballad set in which the evolution of her vocal performance was noted by critics. The next year, she released ''[[Bittersweet White Light]]'', an all-standard album produced at Sonny's insistence, which was a major bomb.{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=81}}{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=82}} Cher scored her second number-one hit with "[[Half-Breed (song)|Half-Breed]]" in 1973, from the RIAA-certified gold [[Half-Breed (album)|album of the same name]].{{cite web|first=Fred |last=Bronson |url=http://www.superseventies.com/sw_halfbreed.html |title="Half-Breed" - Cher |publisher=Billboard |work=The Billboard Book of Number One Hits |year=1988 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} In 1974, she had her third number-one hit with "[[Dark Lady (song)|Dark Lady]]", also from the [[Dark Lady (album)|album of the same name]].{{harvnb|Bronson|1997|p=359}} By late 1972, Cher's marriage with Sonny was over, but appearances were maintained until 1974.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20125200,00.html |title=On the Record |work=People |date=1998-05-11 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} "The public still thinks we are married," Sonny wrote in his diary at the time, "[and] that's the way it has to be."{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/cher-marries-greg-allman |title=Cher marries Greg Allman — This Day in History — 6/30/1975 |work=[[History (TV channel)|History]] |accessdate=2012-10-28}} The end of their marriage became public by the third season of ''The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour''. The show imploded, while still in the top ten of the ratings.{{cite web|first=Billy |last=Ingram |url=http://www.tvclassics.com/sc.htm |title=Sonny and Cher |work=TVClassics.com |accessdate=2012-10-28}} What followed was a troubled, very public divorce, finalized on June 27, 1975.{{cite web|url=http://www.history.com/this-day-in-history/sonny-and-chers-divorce-becomes-final |title=Sonny and Cher's divorce becomes final — This Day in History — 6/26/1975 |work=History |accessdate=2012-10-28}} During the divorce proceedings, Cher lived a two-year relationship with record executive [[David Geffen]], who freed the singer from her business arrangement with Sonny Bono, under which she was required to work exclusively for Cher Enterprises, the company he controlled.{{cite web|first=Bill |last=Higgins |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/grammys-cher-david-geffen-289539 |title=How David Geffen Romanced Cher and Built a Music Empire |work=The Hollywood Reporter |date=2012-11-02 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Around this time, she also had well-known flirts with actor [[Marlon Brando]] and singer [[Elvis Presley]]. She also said that she could play herself in the show.{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/news/cher-musical-in-development-new-album-tour-1007424552.story |title=Cher Musical in Development; New Album, Tour in the Works |work=Billboard |first=Keith |last=Caulfield |date=2012-06-26 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} == Musical style == [[File:Joan Baez Bob Dylan crop.jpg|thumb|170px|[[Bob Dylan]] ''(image)'' was one of the writers who prevailed in Cher's early career repertoire]] Continuously adapting to the trends of each era, Cher's musical style has been the subject of controversy by critics. She is, by record producer Snuff Garrett's analysis, "more of a stylist than a singer"; however, to former senior VP of artist development at Warner Bros. Craig Kostich, "She is a one-of-a-kind artist that continually pushes the boundaries of her talent."{{cite journal|last=Flick|first=Larry|date=1998-10-31|title=Cher Wants You To 'Believe' In Pop|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=110|issue=44|page=12|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=IwoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA12|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}} Cher has worked in numerous music genres, such as folk, disco, rock, [[R&B]], and dance, in order to "remain relevant and do work that strikes a chord." Peter Fawthrop of Allmusic stated that, despite its frequent changes, Cher's musical style always seems "just as sincere and just as much Cher as the previous change" and that "Her personality is set in stone and shines through." He added that Cher sounds as recognizable on the "synthetically vocalized" song "Believe" (1999) as on her "grimly comedic folk" song "Dark Lady" (1974), and concluded that "Those who like Cher's '90s material will probably like Cher back then, even though the music is completely different."{{cite web|last=Fawthrop |first=Peter |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/dark-lady-mw0000840430 |title=Dark Lady - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} {{Listen | filename = Gypys, tramps & thieves.ogg | title = "Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves" (1971) | description = "[[Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves (song)|Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves]]" and her other number-one hits in the same style, "[[Half-Breed (song)|Half-Breed]]" and "[[Dark Lady (song)|Dark Lady]]", "were dramatic, highly intense performances, almost as much 'acted' as sung, and very different from her 1960s output." | filename2 = Believe - Cher.ogg | title2 = "Believe" (1998) | description2 = "[[Believe (Cher song)|Believe]]" is noted for its use of a sound effect on the vocals (using the then newly invented [[Auto-Tune]] software), which is referred to as the "[[Cher effect]]" today }} In the 1960s and 1970s, Cher worked in music genres ranging from [[girl group]] ballads to [[Jackie Deshannon]] folk-influenced pop, to [[adult contemporary]] pop. Her first album, ''All I Really Want to Do'' (1965), was, like most of her solo work in the 1960s, predominantly folk-rock and based in the songbooks of writers like Bob Dylan, [[Pete Seeger]], DeShannon, and her musical partner Sonny Bono, who produced a large part of her 1960s material.{{cite web|last=Sendra |first=Tim |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/all-i-really-want-to-do-mw0000457386 |title=All I Really Want to Do - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Joe Viglione of Allmusic wrote that her 1967 album ''With Love, Chér'' "shows why the singer endeared herself to listeners and got to play in the same ballpark as [[Dusty Springfield|Dusty [Springfield]]] and [[Petula Clark|Petula [Clark]]]".{{cite web|last=Viglione |first=Joe |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/with-love-cher-mw0000373039 |title=With Love, Cher - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} A song from this album, "You Better Sit Down Kids", dealt with divorce, an unusual subject for a 1960s pop record, and was one of a series of releases on which Cher's music broached difficult areas such as unwanted pregnancy. While Cher's first albums were "expressive and radiant", her early-1970s material presented a more adult point of view and personality, as "Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves". For Bruce Eder of Allmusic, "the song's subject matter, unusual tempo changes, and an incredibly memorable chorus-book became a vehicle for a transcendent performance by the singer, marking Cher's maturation as an artist". He also commented that her early-1970s hits were "dramatic, highly intense performances, almost as much 'acted' as sung". He concluded that, despite having "a relatively narrow singing range" at the time, Cher had brought virtues to her music ("tremendous intensity and passion" and "an ability to meld that projection with her acting skills") that resulted into "an incredibly powerful experience for the listener."{{cite web|last=Eder |first=Bruce |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/half-breed-mw0000615307 |title=Half Breed - Cher |work=AllMusic |date=1995-01-01 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Another song from this period, "The Way of Love", is either about a woman expressing her love for another woman, or a woman breaking up with a gay male she loved ("What will you do/When he sets you free/Just the way that you/Said good-bye to me"). Viglione wrote that she "never minded [[Androgyny|androgynous]] or neutral gender identity in her songs" and that "her solo material could soar to heights not possible in a partnership" because of her ability to carry both male and female ranges.{{cite web|last=Viglione |first=Joe |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/gypsys-tramps-thieves-mw0000309635 |title=Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves - Cher |work=AllMusic |date=1971-06-18 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} [[File:Heart of Stone tour 1990 (2).jpg|thumb|left|170px|Cher, seen here on the Heart of Stone Tour, released in the late 1980s and early 1990s a trilogy of rock albums that had revitalized her career]] In 1979, Cher cut two [[disco music]] albums: ''Take Me Home'' and ''Prisoner''. The former presented "loud, rhythmic, danceable" beats, while the latter was an autobiographical mix of disco and rock songs.{{harvnb|Berman|2001|pp=44–46}}{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=137}} Her 1980's album ''Black Rose'' contained all-male background singers, guitar work, multilayered keyboards, and an "ass-kicking attitude" in her vocals to cement her new "rock and roll" persona.{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=142}} It was followed by a series of rock albums that had revitalized her pop career: ''Cher'' (1987), ''Heart of Stone'' (1989) and ''Love Hurts'' (1991).{{cite web|last=McCombs |first=Joseph |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/love-hurts-mw0000264020 |title=Love Hurts - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Those albums shared a distinctive production style, characterized by "stressing" power chords, numerous backup singers, resonant keyboard blasts, and a repertoire of pop rock power ballad songs. The trilogy was also noted for having highlighted Cher's sexually autonomous persona through her "determined and chipper" vocals.{{cite web|last=McCombs |first=Joseph |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/love-hurts-mw0000264020 |title=Love Hurts - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-11-03}}{{cite web|first=Jim |last=Farber |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,314608,00.html |title=Love Hurts Review |work=Entertainment Weekly |date=1991-06-14 |accessdate=2012-11-03}} For the album ''It's a Man's World'' (1995), Cher chose "steamy, torchy" ballads, [[Western (genre)|Western]]-themed [[Epic (genre)|epic]]s, and R&B influences to capitalize on the mid-1990s R&B/pop phenomenon.{{cite web|last=Promis |first=Jose F. |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/its-a-mans-world-mw0000178930 |title=It's a Man's World - Cher |work=AllMusic |date=1996-06-25 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Her vocals were restrained and she sang the songs in higher registers, cutting her [[vibrato]] and revealing "vibrant and previously unheard colors of her voice", as well as a "surprisingly soulful falseto" in the song "One by One".{{cite journal|last=Bessman|first=Jim|date=1996-05-18|title=Cher Changes Approach For Her 'Man's World' On Reprise|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=108|issue=20|page=15|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uA0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}}{{cite journal|last=Verna|first=Paul|date=1996-07-13|title=Albums: Cher - It's A Man's World|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=108|issue=28|page=95|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ogkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA95|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}} Her 1998 album ''Believe'' was directed to her European audience, presenting [[uptempo]] pop confections while incorporating the U.S. brand of [[downtempo]] [[funk]]. The title track had an electronic vocal effect called [[Auto-Tune]], which was suggested by Cher. It became known as the "Cher effect" and later received credit for having "revolutionized record-making."{{cite web|url=http://www.soundonsound.com/sos/feb99/articles/tracks661.htm |title=Recording Cher's 'Believe' |work=Sound On Sound |first=Sue |last=Sillitoe |first=Matt |last=Bell |date=February 1999 |accessdate=2012-10-28}}{{cite journal|last=Verna|first=Paul|date=2000-06-24|title=Studio Monitor: Recording Pros Tune In To Antares' Novel Processors|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=112|issue=26|page=78|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rg8EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA78|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}} Her next album, ''Living Proof'' (2001), included heavy, electronic beats and lyrics about heartbreak, loneliness, and survival. It was also marked by the proeminent use of Auto-Tune, which gave Cher's voice a "canned electronic robot" sound.{{cite web|last=Smith |first=Kerry L. |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/living-proof-mw0000658398 |title=Living Proof - Cher |work=AllMusic |date=2002-02-26 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Vocally, Cher is known for her distinctive [[contralto]], which has been described as "large", "dark", "husky" and "smoky".{{cite news|last=Holden|first=Stephen|title=CABARET REVIEW; On Life's Rough-and-Tumble, via Mama's Tender Heart|work=The New York Times|page=5|date=18 December 1997|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1997/12/18/arts/cabaret-review-on-life-s-rough-and-tumble-via-mama-s-tender-heart.html}}{{cite news|last=Powers|first=Ann|title=POP REVIEW; Quirky but Real, the Beat Goes On|work=The New York Times|page=1|date=7 July 1999|url=http://www.nytimes.com/1999/07/07/arts/pop-review-quirky-but-real-the-beat-goes-on.html}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bostonphoenix.com/boston/music/live/documents/02358065.htm |title=Live & On Record | CHER'S " LIVING PROOF " |work=Boston Phoenix |first=Clea |last=Simon |date=July 18–25, 2002 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} For journalist Robert Fontenot, "Cher possessed one of the greatest and most unusual singing voices of her time".{{cite web|url=http://oldies.about.com/od/60srockers/p/sonnyandcher.htm |first=Robert |last=Fontenot |title=Sonny and Cher Profile |work=About.com |accessdate=2012-10-28}} [[Ann Powers]] of ''The New York Times'' stated that she has "a quintessential rock voice: impure, quirky, a fine vehicle for projecting personality." Cher was praised for her songwriting efforts, particularly in the album ''Not.com.mercial'' (2000), the only of her career with a majority of the songs written by herself. Jose F. Promis of Allmusic wrote that the album presents a "1970s singer/songwriter feel" with "quite engaging lyrics" that proves "Cher adept in the role of storyteller."{{cite web|last=Promis |first=Jose F. |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/notcommercial-mw0000968870 |title=Not.Com.mercial - Cher |work=AllMusic |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Another of her compositions, "My Song", a song co-written with musician [[Mark Hudson (musician)|Mark Hudson]] for her album ''Take Me Home'' (1979) about her relationship with Gregg Allman, was described by Keith Tuber of ''[[Orange Coast Magazine]]'' as "revealing psychologically". He added that "While some of the lyrics are contrived and forced, their honesty and the feeling Cher puts into it more than compensates ... Poignant, tearful, tragic, true. And beautifully recorded."{{cite journal|last=Tuber|first=Keith|date=April 1979|title=Music: Cher - Take Me Home|journal=Orange Coast Magazine|publisher=[[Emmis Communications]]|volume=5|issue=4|page=76|issn=0279-0483|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=Zg0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA76|accessdate=2012-10-28|ref=harv}} == Legacy and public image == {{See also|List of awards and nominations received by Cher|Cher as a gay icon}} {{multiple image |align = left |direction = vertical |image1 = Sonny & Cher Show 1977.JPG |caption1 = Cher, seen here with Sonny Bono on a skit of ''The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour'', is noted as being the first woman to expose her belly button on television |width1 = 170 |image2 = Farrah Fawcett Cher 1976.JPG |caption2 = Cher ''(right)'', seen here with [[Farrah Fawcett]] at ''The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour'', became a fashion trendsetter with her [[Bob Mackie]]-designed outfits |width2 = 170 }} Cher has appeared on the cover of ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine 13 times.{{cite web|author=BettyConfidential.com |url=http://shine.yahoo.com/work-money/20-little-known-facts-about-cher-2411899.html |title=20 Little-Known Facts About Cher |work=Yahoo! Shine |date=2010-11-18 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} She figured twice on ''People'''s annual list of the "25 most intriguing people", in 1975 and 1987.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/issue/0,,7566751229,00.html |title=Intriguing Gypsy : Dec 29, 1975 |work=People |date=1975-12-29 |accessdate=2012-10-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/issue/0,,7566871228,00.html |title=Princess Diana Tests The Limits : Dec 28, 1987 |work=People |date=1987-12-28 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} She was also featured on the "100 Greatest Movie Stars of our Time" list compiled by the magazine.{{harvnb|Laufenberg|2005|p=120}} In 1992, [[Madame Tussauds]] wax museum immortalized her with a life-size statue as one of the five most beautiful women of history.{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=BXZlprZRTJoC&lpg=PR1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA165|page=165|accessdate=2012-10-29|title=The Homeopathic Revolution: Why Famous People and Cultural Heroes Choose Homeopathy|author=Dana Ullman|date=2007-10-16|publisher=North Atlantic Books|isbn=1556436718}} In 1999, Cher received the [[World Music Awards#Legend Awards|Legend Award]] at the [[World Music Awards]] for her "lifelong contribution to the music industry".{{cite journal|last=Dezzani|first=Mark|date=1999-05-22|title=Smith Leads A More Polished WMAs|journal=Billboard|publisher=Nielsen Business Media|location=New York|volume=111|issue=21|page=52|issn=0006-2510|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=ig0EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA52|accessdate=2012-10-30|ref=harv}} In a 2001 poll, [[A&E (TV channel)|A&E]]'s ''Biography'' magazine ranked her as the third favorite leading actress of all time behind [[Audrey Hepburn]] and [[Katharine Hepburn]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Audrey+Hepburn+Named+Favorite+All-Time+Oscar-Winning+Actress+by...-a075081004 |title=Audrey Hepburn Named Favorite All-Time Oscar-Winning Actress by Biography Magazine Readers. - Free Online Library |publisher=Free Online Library |year=2001 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} In 2002, she was honored with the Artist Achievement Award at [[Billboard Music Awards]] for having "helped redefine popular music through success on the ''Billboard'' charts." In 2010, she ranked 44th on the "75 Greatest Women of All Time" list compiled by ''[[Esquire]]'' magazine.{{cite web|url=http://www.esquire.com/women/women-issue/greatest-women-in-history#slide-44 |title=Greatest Women in History - 75 Greatest American Women |work=Esquire |accessdate=2012-10-30}} Cher has stated she finds "strange" being the recipient of such honors; after she was honored with a Lifetime Achievement Award by ''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'' magazine in 2010, she said, "It's like the kiss of death when you get honored for a lifetime achievement. It's like okay, it's over, this is your lifetime and you've achieved whatever you're going to achieve."{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Cher/articles/yzuxjztH_mv/Cher+Lifetime+Achievement+Award+Kiss+Death |title=Cher on Lifetime Achievement Award: 'It's the Kiss of Death' |work=Zimbio |date=2010-11-09 |accessdate=2012-10-31}} Although Cher's regular exposure on television in the 1970s allowed people to see and hear her without having to buy her records, she has sold over 100 million albums worldwide.{{cite web|author=M. Alex Johnson |url=http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/23059743#.TxCK5qVrOBs |title=Cher inks three-year deal for Caesars Palace shows |work=TODAY.com |date=2008-02-07 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} She is the only person in history to receive an Academy Award, a Grammy Award, an Emmy Award, a Golden Globe Award and the Best Actress Award at the Cannes Film Festival.{{cite web|url=http://jornaldeangola.sapo.ao/24/0/cher_faz_lembrar_michael_jackson |title=Cher faz lembrar Michael Jackson |work=Jornal de Angola |date=2011-09-12 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} {{external media|width=200px| image1=[http://img.timeinc.net/time/magazine/archive/covers/1975/1101750317_400.jpg Cher's ''Time''] cover from March 17, 1975}} Cher's outrageous fashion sense has inducted controversy over the years. In May 1999, after she was honored by the [[Council of Fashion Designers of America]] with a special award for her influence in fashion, [[Robin Givhan]] of ''Los Angeles Times'' called her a "fashion visionary" for "striking just the right note of contemporary wretched excess". She cited [[Tom Ford]], [[Anna Sui]] and [[Dolce & Gabbana]] as "Influential designers [who] have evoked her name as a source of inspiration and guidance." She concluded that "Cher's Native American showgirl sexpot persona now seems to epitomize the fashion industry's rush to celebrate ethnicity, adornment and sex appeal."{{cite web|first=Robin |last=Givhan |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1999/may/14/news/cl-36955 |title=And the Fashion Award Goes to ... Cher? |work=Los Angeles Times |date=1999-05-14 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} Cher emerged as a fashion trendsetter in the 1960s, popularizing the jet black long hair, [[bell bottom]]s, bare [[midriff]], bandanas, Cherokee-inspired tunics, bangs, black eyeliner, and bobcat vests.{{cite web|first=Christa |last=Fletcher |url=http://www.ehow.co.uk/slideshow_12239708_controversial-trendsetters.html#pg=12 |title=25 Most controversial trendsetters |work=[[eHow]] |accessdate=2012-10-30}}{{cite web|url=http://xfinity.comcast.net/slideshow/entertainment-cherslooks/ |title=The singer-actress-legend, now starring in "Burlesque," recalls her fabulously daring, forever-memorable fashion moves. |work=InStyle.com |accessdate=2012-10-30}} She began working as a model in 1967 for photographer [[Richard Avedon]], after being discovered by the then-''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine director [[Diana Vreeland]]. Avedon took the famous photo of her in a beaded and feathered nude gown for the cover of ''Time'' magazine in 1975.{{cite web|first=Nojan |last=Aminosharei |url=http://www.elle.com/fashion/spotlight/fashion-high-notes-446376#slide-5 |title=Influential Women in Music - Influential Musicians |work=ELLE |date=2010-06-01 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} Cher has appeared five times on the cover of ''Vogue'', between 1972 and 1975.{{cite news|last=Wilson |first=Eric |url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/15/fashion/vogues-archives-go-online.html?_r=0 |title=Vogue's Archives Go Online |work=New York Times |date=2011-12-14 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} Through her 1970s television shows, she became a [[sex symbol]] with her inventive and revealing [[Bob Mackie]]-designed outfits, and fought the network censors to bare her [[Navel|belly button]].{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=7GN0E_diWbAC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA82|page=82|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=From Abba to Zoom: A Pop Culture Encyclopedia of the Late 20th Century|date=2005-06-01|publisher=Andrews McMeel Publishing|isbn=0740793071}} She is noted as being the first woman to expose her belly button on television. ''People'' magazine regarded Cher as the "pioneer of the belly beautiful".{{cite news|title=Bare navels back in fashion|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=ygYqAAAAIBAJ&sjid=gRIEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2326,5459060&dq=actress+navel&hl=en|accessdate=2012-03-17|newspaper=The Milwaukee Sentinel|date=1986-04-14}} Booth Moore of ''Los Angeles Times'' wrote that "they don't make style icons like Cher anymore. From the beginning of her career ... she understood that cultivating a look was as important as cultivating a sound. Unlike today's stars, Cher wasn't a billboard for sale to the highest bidder. She was the world's [[Barbie]] doll, a living fashion fantasy week after week on TV, who landed simultaneously on best—and worst—dressed lists. Love her or hate her, she always keeps us guessing."{{cite web|first=Booth |last=Moore |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2008/may/18/image/ig-notebook18 |title=The diva master |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2008-05-18 |accessdate=2012-10-28}} Cher's video for "[[Hell on Wheels#Music video|Hell on Wheels]]" (1979) holds the distinction of being one of the first rock videos ever produced in the "MTV style", even before its existence. Her "risqué" video for "[[If I Could Turn Back Time#Music video|If I Could Turn Back Time]]" (1989), in which she donned fishnet stockings and notoriously straddled the [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] battleship [[USS Missouri (BB-63)|USS ''Missouri'']]'s 16-inch guns, was the first ever to be banned by MTV.{{cite web|url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Sep/18/ln/hawaii909180372.html |title=Retired battleship Mighty Mo to get makeover at Hawaii drydock |work=The Honolulu Advertiser |first=Dan |last=Nakaso |date=2009-07-18 |accessdate=2012-10-30}}{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=kafLPlbiy4EC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA193|page=193|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=Working Girls: Gender and Sexuality in Popular Cinema|author=Yvonne Tasker|date=1998-05-22|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0415140048}} Cher's enduring success in various areas of entertainment earned her the nickname "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Goddess of Pop]]".{{cite web|last=Sidman |first=Amanda |url=http://articles.nydailynews.com/2010-11-20/gossip/27081751_1_bumper-car-cher-veteran-performer |title='Burlesque' star Cher still going strong: 'I feel like a bumper car, I just don't stop' |work=New York Daily News |date=2010-11-20 |accessdate=2012-10-30}}{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/article-1328973/Cher-64-makes-statement-slashed-leggings.html |title=Cher, 64, makes a statement in a see-through top and slashed leggings |work=Daily Mail |date=2010-11-12 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} Throughout her career she has repeatedly reinvented herself through a series of "whole new" personas.{{harvnb|Bego|2004|p=7}} Biographer [[Mark Bego]] wrote, "No one in the history of show business has had a career of the magnitude and scope of Cher's. She has been a teenage pop star, a television hostess, a fashion magazine model, a rock star, a pop singer, a Broadway actress, an Academy Award-winning movie star, a disco sensation, and the subject of a mountain of press coverage." Author [[Lucy O'Brien]] stated that "Cher adheres to the [[American Dream]] of reinvention of self: 'Getting old does not have to mean getting obsolete.'"{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=cEDqNRkk6KIC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA130|page=130|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=Girls Rock!: Fifty Years of Women Making Music|author=Mina Carson|author2=Tisa Lewis|author3=Susan M. Shaw|date=2004-07-23|publisher=University Press of Kentucky|isbn=0813123100}} She also wrote in her book ''She Bop II: The Definitive History of Women in Rock, Pop and Soul'' that "The Queen of 1980s Rock Chicks had to be Cher ... With her cascading hair, rear-end tattoo, fish-net stockings, black leather jackets and well-publicized romances with young heavy metal heroes ... it was as if she was playing the role of rock star."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=AZ4L0Pv7QwUC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA128|page=128|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=She Bop II: The Definitive History of Women in Rock, Pop and Soul|author=Lucy O'Brien|year=2002|publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group|isbn=0826472087}} Author Craig Crawford claimed that Cher's success was based on "constantly reshaping her image according to what people think", and that she "studiously followed the evolving demands of the cultural marketplace, billing each dramatic turnaround of style as another example of rebellion—an image that allowed her to make calculated changes while appearing to be consistent."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=3gAWYrDC-YYC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA31|page=31|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=The Politics of Life: 25 Rules for Survival in a Brutal and Manipulative World|author=Craig Crawford|date=2007-04-16|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=1442212977}} Conversely, Bego felt that, despite not being the "most talented actress" or "the most gifted vocalist", Cher has builded a career of strength, longevity and "true 'superstar' status" based "as much on her unpredictability as upon her talents". Cher was called "an authentic feminist hero" by ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'' magazine and the "Queen of the Comeback" by ''The New York Times''.{{cite news|first=Stephen |last=Holden |url=http://www.nytimes.com/1996/06/30/arts/pop-jazz-queen-of-the-comeback-cher-tries-yet-again.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm |title=POP/JAZZ;Queen of the Comeback, Cher Tries Yet Again |work=New York Times |date=1996-06-30 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} She was credited by ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' as "the person who paved the way for Madonna, Lady Gaga and many more."{{cite web|first=Dean |last=Richards |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2010-11-20/features/ct-ae-1121-dean-richards-20101120_1_cher-movies-plastic-surgery |title=Cher: More movies may be in store |work=Chicago Tribune |date=2010-11-20 |accessdate=2012-10-31}} Her "integrity" and "perseverance" were highlighted in the ''Reaching Your Goals'' book series of illustrated inspirational readers for children, in which her life was detailed emphasizing the importance of self-actualization: "For years, Cher worked hard to become a successful singer. Then she worked hard to become an actress. Even when she needed money, she turned down movie roles that weren't right for her. Her goal has always been to be a ''good'' actress, not just a rich and famous one."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uLWemXqxatwC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA171|page=171|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=Off-White Hollywood: American Culture and Ethnic Female Stardom|author=Diane Negra|date=2001-10-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0415216788}} Diane Negra, in her book ''Off-White Hollywood: American Culture and Ethnic Female Stardom'', discussed Cher's ability to make comebacks after struggled periods, giving as examples, "the singer associated with hippie radicalism and youth culture in the 1960s becomes an icon of family-oriented entertainment in ''The Sonny and Cher Comedy Hour''; the single mother who dates scandalous rock stars becomes an Academy Award winning actress by 1987; that same film star descends to the low genres of infomercial and catalogue sales in the 1990s, then returns ... with 'quality' projects such as an HBO film on abortion."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=uLWemXqxatwC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA164|page=164|accessdate=2012-10-30|title=Off-White Hollywood: American Culture and Ethnic Female Stardom|author=Diane Negra|date=2001-10-19|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0415216788}} For her part, Cher has stated, "I feel like a bumper car. If I hit a wall, I'm backing up and going in another direction. And I've hit plenty of fucking walls in my career. But I'm not stopping. I think maybe that's my best quality: I just don't stop." Record producer David Geffen declared "Cher is the proverbial cat with nine lives" and that "She is as relevant today as she was ... in the sixties ... She can thrill, shock and amaze; that simply is Cher being Cher."{{cite web|last=Hollandsworth |first=Skip |url=http://www.glamour.com/inspired/women-of-the-year/2010/cher |title=Cher: The Legend: Inspired |work=[[Glamour (magazine)]] |date=2010-11-01 |accessdate=2012-10-30}} ===Plastic surgery=== [[File:Sonny and Cher Sonny and Cher Show 1976.JPG|thumb|170px|left|Cher, seen here performing with Sonny at ''The Sonny & Cher Comedy Hour'', has been accused of replacing her "ethnic" features with a more "conventional" look]] Cher's youthful-looking appearance has long been the subject of intense scrutiny, both by the public and the press. [[Grant McCracken]], author of ''Transformations: Identity Construction in Contemporary Culture'', commented that "Cher has been called the 'poster girl' of plastic surgery." He also drew a parallel between her plastic surgeries and the transformations in her career: "There is no public record of when ... Cher chose to have her plastic surgery. But it does seem more or less consistent with the rest of her transformational career. Her plastic surgery is not merely cosmetic. It is hyperbolic, extreme, over the top ... Cher has engaged in a transformational technology that is dramatic and irreversible."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=YJzy2HmHLBcC&pg=PA27|page=27|accessdate=2012-10-29|title=Transformations: Identity Construction in Contemporary Culture|author=Grant David McCracken|date=2008-05-01|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=0253219574}} Caroline Ramazanoglu, author of ''Up Against Foucault: Explorations of Some Tensions Between Foucault and Feminism'', wrote that "Cher's operations have gradually replaced a strong, decidedly 'ethnic' look with a more symmetrical, delicate, 'conventional' (i.e. [[Anglo-Saxon]]) and ever-youthful version of female beauty ... Cher admits to having had her breasts 'done', her nose bobbed and her teeth straightened; reportedly she has also had a rib removed, her buttocks reshaped, and cheek implants ... Her normalised image ... now acts as a standard against which other women will measure, judge, discipline and 'correct' themselves."{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=rktUPlgqq_gC&pg=PA197|page=197|accessdate=2012-10-29|title=Up Against Foucault: Explorations of Some Tensions Between Foucault and Feminism|author=C. Ramazanoglu|date=1993-12-02|publisher=Routledge|isbn=0415050111}} Cher denies most of the rumors about her plastic surgery, and has stated, "I've had the same cheeks my entire life. No butt lifts. No ribs removed ... If I want to put my tits on my back, it's nobody's business but my own."{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Primetime/story?id=132108&page=1#.TxDZK6VrOBs |title=The World According to Cher - ABC News |work=ABC News |date=2002-02-28 |accessdate=2012-02-14}} === Tattoos === [[File:Heart of Stone tour 1990 (5).jpg|thumb|170px|right|Cher's floral [[tattoo]] on her buttocks]] Cher became famous for her many [[tattoo]]s long before they were fashionable among women and female celebrities.{{cite book|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=xXti7XAwfrQC&lpg=PP1&hl=pt-BR&pg=PA244|page=244|accessdate=2012-10-29|title=Celebrities' Most Wanted™: The Top 10 Book of Lavish Lifestyles, Tabloid Tidbits, and Other Superstar Oddities|author=Marjorie Hallenbeck-Huber|date=2010-06-30|publisher=Potomac Books|isbn=1597975109}} According to the site Vanishing Tattoo, "Cher was one of the first celebrities to openly and enthusiastically embrace tattoos and body art, and with her outrageous sense of style and fashion, she played a pivotal role in the acceptance of tattoos within mainstream popular culture ... Her influence can be seen in the first supermodels that got tattoos[.]"{{cite web|url=http://www.vanishingtattoo.com/tattoo/celeb-cher.htm |title=CHER Tattoo photos pics pictures of her tattoos |work=Vanishing Tattoo |date=2007-07-04 |accessdate=2012-10-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.vanishingtattoo.com/celebrity_tattoos_female_actors_s.htm |title=CELEBRITY ACTRESS TATTOOS - S |work=Vanishing Tattoo |date=2007-07-04 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Among her tattoos were a butterfly and floral design on her buttocks; a flowing necklace on her left upper arm with three charms hanging on it: an [[Egyptian language|Egyptian]] [[ankh]], a cross and a heart; a [[kanji]] on her right shoulder; a small cluster of [[Art Deco]]-like [[crystals]] on her inner right arm; a black orchid design just above the crease of her right thigh; and a [[chrysanthemum]] on her left ankle.{{cite web|url=http://www.bellaonline.com/articles/art41518.asp |title=The Tattoos of Cher |first=Rae |last=Schwarz |work=BellaOnline |accessdate=2012-10-29}} In the late 1990s, Cher began having laser treatments to remove her tattoos.{{cite web|last=Jerome |first=Jim |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20125372,00.html |title=Being Cher |work=People |date=1998-05-25 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} The process went underway in the 2000s. She commented, "When I got tattooed, only bad girls did it: me and [[Janis Joplin]] and biker chicks. Now it doesn't mean anything. No one's surprised. I got a tattoo right after I left Sonny [Bono] and I was feeling real independent. That was my badge."{{cite news| url=http://www.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2008-02-06-cher-side_N.htm | work=USA Today | first=Edna | last=Gundersen | title=Cher shares: Life, love, tattoos, politics, paparazzi | date=February 6, 2008}} == Personal life == ===Humanitarian work=== Cher's primary philanthropic endeavors have included support of health research and patient quality of life, anti-poverty initiatives, veterans rights, and vulnerable children. After her portrayal of the mother of a boy with a facial skull deformity in the 1985 film ''[[Mask]]'', Cher served as a donor and the National Chairperson and Honorary Spokesperson of the [[Children's Craniofacial Association]], whose mission is to "empower and give hope to facially disfigured children and their families". She has held that title since 1990. The annual Cher's Family Retreat is held each June to provide craniofacial patients, their siblings and parents an opportunity to interact with others who have endured similar experiences.{{cite web|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/cher-presents-love-sees-no-color-premiere-at-los-angeles-fundraiser-party-59839397.html |title=Cher Presents 'Love Sees No Color' Premiere at Los Angeles Fundraiser Party |publisher=PRNewswire |work=Nassiri |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Through the years, Cher has often donated concert tickets to families and non-profit groups for children with facial deformities.{{cite web|url=http://www.looktothestars.org/celebrity/cher#ixzz2AhVdrxhq |title=Cher's Charity Work, Events and Causes |work=Look to the Stars |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Cher also supports and actively promotes Get A-Head Charitable Trust, which aims to improve the quality of life for people with head and neck diseases. In 1993, Cher participated in a humanitarian effort in Armenia, taking food and medical supplies to the war-torn region. In 1998, she co-hosted the annual [[amfAR, The Foundation for AIDS Research|American Foundation for AIDS Research]] Benefit at the Cannes Film Festival with [[Elizabeth Taylor]]. She is also the namesake of the Cher Charitable Foundation, which contributes "time and money to charities and causes close to her heart". Cher has been a vocal supporter of American soldiers and returning veterans. She has donated over US $130,000 to Operation Helmet, an organization that provides free helmet upgrade kits to troops in Iraq and Afghanistan. Cher has also contributed to the [[Intrepid Fallen Heroes Fund]] which serves military personnel who have been disabled in operations in Iraq and Afghanistan, and those severely injured in other operations. Cher has engaged in the construction of houses with [[Habitat for Humanity]] and served as the Honorary National Chair of a Habitat's elimination of poverty housing initiative "Raise the Roof", an effort to engage artists in the organization's work while on tour. Cher is also a donor, fundraiser and international spokesperson for [[Keep a Child Alive]], an organization that seeks to accelerate action to combat the global AIDS pandemic, including the provision of Antiretroviral medicine to children and their families with HIV/AIDS. In 2007, Cher became the primary supporter of the Peace Village School (PVS) in [[Ukunda]], Kenya, which "provides nutritious food, medical care, education and extracurricular activities for more than 300 orphans and vulnerable children, ages 2 to 13 years."{{cite web|url=http://cher.com/about-cher/love-cher/cher-helps-save-kenyan-school/ |title=Cher Helps Save Kenyan School |work=Cher.com |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Cher's support enabled the school to acquire land and build permanent housing and school facilities, and in partnership with [[Malaria No More]] and other organizations, she piloted an effort to eliminate [[malaria]] mortality and morbidity for the children, their caregivers and the surrounding community. === Political interests === Although Cher says she's not a registered Democrat, she has attended many [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] conventions and events.{{cite web|last=Wilker |first=Deborah |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Entertainment/story?id=113900&page=1#.UI7BTsWCk4x |title=Cher Begs Voters Not to Choose Bush |work=ABC News |date=2000-11-01 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Over the years, Cher became known for her political views, having been an outspoken critic of the [[Social conservatism|conservative]] movement.{{cite web|last=Goodman |first=Alana |url=http://newsbusters.org/blogs/alana-goodman/2010/11/02/cher-sarah-palin-dumb-woman-jan-brewer-shouldn-t-even-handle-remote-c |title=Cher: Sarah Palin is a 'Dumb Woman,' Jan Brewer Shouldn't Even Handle 'A Remote Control' |work=NewsBusters.org |date=2010-11-02 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} She has commented that she didn't understand why anyone would be a Republican because eight years under the administration of [[George W. Bush]] "almost killed me".{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/washington/2009/02/cher-i-dont-kno.html |title=Cher: 'I don't know why anyone would want to be a Republican' |first=Andrew |last=Malcolm |work=Los Angeles Times |date=2009-02-06 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} During the [[United States presidential election, 2000|2000 United States presidential election]], [[ABC News]] wrote that she was determined to do "whatever possible to keep him [Bush] out of office". She told the site, "If you're black in this country, if you're a woman in this country, if you are any minority in this country at all, what could possibly possess you to vote Republican? ... You won't have one f---ing right left." She also said of George W., "I don't like Bush. I don't trust him. I don't like his record. He's stupid. He's lazy." On October 27, 2003, Cher anonymously called a [[C-SPAN]] phone-in program. She recounted a visit she had made to maimed soldiers at the [[Walter Reed Army Medical Center]] and criticized the lack of media coverage and government attention given to injured servicemen. She also remarked that she watches C-SPAN every day. Though she simply identified herself as an unnamed entertainer, she was recognized by the C-SPAN host, who subsequently questioned her about her 1992 support for independent presidential candidate [[Ross Perot]]. She said, "When I heard him talk right in the beginning, I thought that he would bring some sort of common-sense business approach and also less partisianship, but then ... I was completely disappointed like everyone else when he just kind of cut and run and no one knew exactly why ... Maybe he couldn't have withstood all the investigation that goes on now[.]"{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanarchives.org/clip/37094 |title=Clip: Open Phones |work=C-SPAN Video Library |date=2010-11-05 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} On [[Memorial Day]] weekend in 2006, Cher called into C-SPAN's ''[[Washington Journal]]'' endorsing Operation Helmet, a group that provides helmets to help soldiers avoid head injuries while in the war zone.{{cite web|last=Wolf |first=Buck |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/story?id=2081111&page=1#.UI68vsWCk4y |title=Cher Goes to Washington |work=ABC News |date=2006-06-15 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} On June 14, 2006, she made a guest appearance on C-SPAN with Dr. Bob Meaders, founder of Operation Helmet.{{cite web|url=http://www.c-spanvideo.org/program/192937-6 |title=Operation Helmet |work=C-SPAN Video Library |date=2006-06-14 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} That same year, in an interview with ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'' newspaper, Cher explained her "against the war in Iraq but for the troops" position: "I don't have to be for this war to support the troops because these men and women do what they think is right. They do what they're told to do. They do it with a really good heart. They do the best they can. They don't ask for anything."{{cite web|first=Steve |last=Mraz |url=http://www.stripes.com/news/cher-i-don-t-have-to-be-for-this-war-to-support-the-troops-1.51650 |title=Cher: 'I don't have to be for this war to support the troops' |work=Stars and Stripes |date=2006-07-16 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} Cher supported [[Hillary Clinton]] in her Presidential campaign: "I like Hillary. I think she'd make the best president. I think [[[Barack Obama]]]'s a good man. I think he's altruistic. I think he's smart. I think at some point he can be a great leader. I just don't think it's now."{{cite web|first=Charles |last=Winters |url=http://www.zimbio.com/Senator+Hillary+Clinton+Of+New+York/articles/257/Quote+Day+Cher+endorses+Hillary+Clinton+President |title=Quote of the Day: Cher endorses Hillary Clinton for President |work=Zimbio |date=2008-02-09 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} After Obama won the Democratic nomination, Cher supported his candidacy on TV programs.{{cite web|last=Dickens |first=Geoffrey |url=http://newsbusters.org/blogs/geoffrey-dickens/2008/10/30/cher-endorses-obama-bashes-bush-today |title=Cher Endorses Obama, Bashes Bush on 'Today' |work=NewsBusters.org |date=2008-10-30 |accessdate=2012-10-29}}{{cite web|url=http://www.zimbio.com/Famous+Democrats/articles/FOQwxd5zS39/Cher |title=Cher - Famous Democrats |work=Zimbio |date=2010-12-17 |accessdate=2012-10-29}} However, in a 2010 interview with ''Vanity Fair'' magazine, she commented that she "still thinks Hillary would have done a better job", although she "accepts the fact that Barack Obama inherited insurmountable problems". During the interview, she also stood against American politicians [[Sarah Palin]] ("Palin came on, and I thought, Oh, fuck, this is the end. Because a dumb woman is a dumb woman") and the then-[[Arizona]] governor [[Jan Brewer]]: "She was worse than Sarah Palin, if that is possible. This woman was like a deer in headlights.
